text: I have been using the Oneplus Buds Z2 for more than a 1.5 years now and that is perhaps the best TWS headphones at that given price. It has great features, great sound, great battery life and good noise cancellation. But I was still searching for another TWS. Why? Because I am not a fan of bass. My only two reasons for not liking the Buds Z2 is that it is bass heavy, and it is too loud. This is what most people want, but my music preferences are not like that. So when I read reviews about the Sony WF C500, I thought of buying it. But that changed was that I got the Song WF C700N at under 5000 in the Great Indian Festival. And what impressed me most the most is the sound. The sound isn‚Äôt too bassy. It balanced. Some might call it flat and boring too. Because it won‚Äôt excite you if you are someone who loves bass. But I loved the sound. I was amazed what a 5 mm dynamic driver could do. Yes, small driver means the volume isn‚Äôt as loud as Oneplus, but I could never use the Oneplus over 20 percent volume as it would hurt my ears. The Sony is much more soft and has a warm sound tone. It packs good punch and if you want you have a full equaliser at your disposal in the Headphones Connect app. And you can play along with the already created profiles or make custom ones. Adjust the sound to your likings and you will be amazed at the sound. The connection is easy too and the app is easy to use. I would say for the price I got it at, the sound punches much above the class.But that‚Äôs about it. If you look for features, look away. The buds have a continuous battery backup of around 8 hours approximately and the case holds one additional charge. You will get approximately 16 hours of playtime with ANC turned on. The case takes 3 hours ro fully charge however there is a fast charge feature where you can charge for 10 mis and use for some 2-4 hours. There are no touch controls, however the buttons are very tactile and a breeze to use. The buds have IPX4 though. And it is one of the lightest set of TWS I have ever used. So don‚Äôt look for any features. As the competition offer much more at lesser price.But that I loved, I will repeat again, is the sound. And the customisation available for the sound. The experience is premium. The connection is easy for both Android and iOS. For someone who loves to play around with different types of music, this is a great pair of TWS if you get it under 6000 I would say. This would be an audiophile‚Äôs dream budget TWS if you look at it that way. But it for the amazing sound and nothing else.

Put it in the case for a minute and it was good. Also that day the right unit began losing signal suddenly, despite being within 2 or 3 metres of the phone, line of sight being unblocked. I thought maybe it happens in bluetooth earphones and isn't a big issue.The issue amplified in the upcoming days. The right unit kept losing signal and kept powering off itself randomly, sometimes it could power on sometimes it couldn't.Today, it couldn't even power on after putting it in case. All I could hear is a static sound coming on and off in a few seconds from the right unit, its trying to do something but it isnt succeeding.I brought it for Rs 5666 in Feb 2023 from seller Appario. I've ordered several items from them in the past and they've not let me down.I've concluded that this unit is a bust. Bad luck, I got a lemon. Should have doubted that something is wrong with it when it was selling for a discount. There are manufacturing issues with 1 to 5% of the products, that's how good things are manufactured these days, so when you end up with something defective it's a sour experience. And before you ask, I've been taking great care of them by not wearing them in weird places like toilet and shower.Warranty is a thorny road, and so is replacement. The amount of red tape surrounding warranty is obnoxious. Since I trusted Sony name I took a chance that these units will last but they didnt and my chance for asking a replacement gone. Got no other option other than biting the bullet and eat the cost. Even if I get a replacement, this lemon is going to end up in refurbished market where some other poor fellow would buy this sour lemon again and get his taste soury.Bottom line- be ready to eat the cost of product in case it's a lemon, don't rely on warranty and replacement policies because they are always tipped in favour of the seller/manufacturer.Update: Made up my mind to dispose it off. text: Review:I had high hopes for the Sony WF-C500 earphones, but my experience with them has been nothing short of a nightmare. Not only did the charging case heat up to dangerous levels, causing it to melt, but now the earbuds themselves refuse to charge. It's clear that Sony's quality control has taken a nosedive, and their customer service is equally disappointing.First and foremost, let's address the most alarming issue: the charging case. Imagine my shock when I noticed that it was emitting excessive heat while charging, and before I knew it, the case had melted! I can't stress enough how dangerous this situation is. Sony, a reputed company, should have implemented strict safety measures to prevent such hazards. I shudder to think of the potential consequences if I hadn't been around to notice the overheating. It's simply unacceptable.Naturally, I immediately reached out to Sony's customer service, hoping for a swift resolution. However, instead of offering a prompt replacement or refund, they had the audacity to demand 1490 rupees from me! Seriously? It's as if they're trying to profit from their own product's failure. Charging customers for a defective product is nothing short of extortion.To add insult to injury, their warranty claim process is a convoluted mess. They've made it intentionally difficult to navigate, likely hoping that frustrated customers will simply give up and purchase a new set of earphones instead. It's a shameful tactic, and it reeks of a company that cares more about their bottom line than the satisfaction and safety of their customers.I'm deeply disappointed.
